posts.text: The article you linked doesn't seem to corroborate your hinted "complicating matters". Their findings corroborate the intuitive hypothesis that yes, Spanish mothers over the last 500 years lived shorter lives, correlated with the age at which they became mothers and number of kids they had to raise.

reply_context.text:
seems like this would make sense.

* pregnancy reduces mobility, increasing vulnerability to predation
* giving birth has a non-trivial fatality risk
* caregiving is energetically costly, stressful/physically taxing, draws attention of predators, and creates an incentive for self-sacrifice

1/ We found that deep sequence models memorize atomic facts "geometrically" -- not as an associative lookup table as often imagined.

This opens up practical questions on reasoning/memory/discovery, and also poses a theoretical "memorization puzzle."
normal times, you'd expect to see them easing off the use of force immediately following a bad shoot like yesterday. this happens the day after, feels like it's not a coincidence.

books aren't the only text protected by copyright. how long does the document need to be for this to be valid? is this true for memorizing a TV script? a speech? are you asserting that reconstruction of any continuous text of any length implies the model had to have seen the full document?

reply_context.text: The per-sequence probabilities sliding throughout a given text show that *in-order* sequence probabilities are enormous. Most parsimonious explanation was training on whole documents. Don't find talking with this degree of asymmetric information useful. Once again, will refer you to the above paper.

posts.text: we know something akin to piecemeal reconstruction has to be possible because that's how non-memorization factual knowledge is learned. arxiv.org/abs/2503.21676

reply_context.text: maybe I'm misunderstanding, but I imagine the kind of controlled conditions that would be required to interrogate the scenario I described would include controlling the training data. you don't know under what conditions piecemeal reconstruction could occur or that it never does.

posts.text: maybe I'm misunderstanding, but I imagine the kind of controlled conditions that would be required to interrogate the scenario I described would include controlling the training data. you don't know under what conditions piecemeal reconstruction could occur or that it never does.

reply_context.text: As noted in my prior message, this is addressed in our prior work on open-weight models, where we study this topic under more controlled conditions.

posts.text: Local news needs a much better way of making money from stories they break of national importance. Nobody who clicks this is paying for a subscription, but they might chip in a buck or 2.

regardless whether or not this is what's actually going on for the items/models you investigated, the question is still valid and merits discussion. and if you want to rule out the possibility that this situation is relevant to your work, that is a separate set of experiments you need to perform.

reply_context.text: For these results (as well as those in our open-weights paper from 6 months ago: arxiv.org/abs/2505.12546), this is extremely unlikely as an explanation. We measure how much of the book we extracted _in order_, starting from a short prompt at the beginning.
